The 100th Congress begins its session tomorrow, and is a very different body than the one that first met in 1789. The following is a comparison of the two congresses. Some figures, such as those on legisltaion, are for the 99th Congress. STAFF AND COSTS First Congress It cost $373,853 to run the first congress. The Senate staff consisted of a Secretary of Senate and two clerks, chaplain, doorkeeper and messenger. The House had a Clerk of House, two clerks, a chaplain, doorkeeper, assistant doorkeeper, and sergeant at arms. (Source: First Federal Congress Project at George Washington University; Congressional offices) 100th Congress It will cost $3.2 billion, for the two years ending Sept. 30, 1987, to operate the 100th Congress. There are 11,064 staff members for the House and approximately 7,200 for the Senate. (Sources: Congressional Quarterly; Congressional offices) THE BUSINESS OF CONGRESS First Congress 143 measures were introduced in the House, and 24 in the Senate. A total of 117 of bills were enacted. There was one standing committee each in the House and the Senate, although special commitees were formed to consider particular pieces of legislation. (Source: Congressional Record) 99th Congress 7,522 measures were introduced in the House and 4,080 in the Senate. A total of 664 bills were enacted. There were 31 standing committees in the House and 24 in the Senate. (Source: Congressional Record) PAY AND ALLOWANCES First Congress Pay was $6 a day for each day in session. Ther was a travel allowance of $6 for every 20 miles of the estimated distance by a normal route to the seat of Congress. (Source: Congressional offices) 100th Congress The salary for both senators and representatives is $77,400. In the House, expenses for the year ending Dec. 31, 1987 is $64,380,000 for staff and $176,853,600 for offices. The Senate will spend $104,030,000 for staff, and $6,100,000 for office expenses, in the same period. (Source: Congressional offices) WASHINGTON TALK Correction: January 28, 1987, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition and January 6, 1987, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

A chart yesterday on the Washington Talk page, comparing the Congress of today with the first Congress, misstated the number of standing committees in the 99th Congress. The House had 22 and the Senate 16. In addition, it reversed the figures for the number of days each Congress met. In the First Congress the House met 377 days and the Senate 366 days.
For the 99th Congress, the House met 281 days and the Senate 313 days.
